Biochemistry. 1984; 23: 85-90Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar), MQPA was studied to compare its inhibitory activity for human mast cell tryptase with MNAPPA. The result shown in Table I that MQPA as well as MNAPPA did not inhibit tryptase up to the concentration of 60 μm provided additional clear evidence indicating their high selectivity for thrombin and trypsin, respectively. The IC50 values of MNAPPA for trypsin, thrombin, plasmin, and tryptase were compared with several established trypsin inhibitors in Table II. All of the trypsin inhibitors tested except SBTI inhibited both of trypsin and tryptase. Although SBTI discriminated trypsin from tryptase, it inhibited plasmin rather strongly. Consequently, MNAPPA was a highly selective trypsin inhibitor among those inhibitors tested. In particular, MNAPPA was the first small molecular weight inhibitor that discriminated trypsin from tryptase precisely.Table IIEnzyme profiles of proteinase inhibitorsInhibitorIC50ThrombinPlasminTrypsinTryptaseμmMNAPPA60>600.3>60Leupeptin>10020.20.4Antipain>100400.40.3Nafamostat mesilate300.30.030.001SBTI>300.040.00920 Open table in a new tab We attempted to get insight into the molecular mechanism of trypsin-specific inhibition of MNAPPA with a computer-aided modeling technique. Because MQPA has been reported to bind the active site of trypsin and thrombin in nearly identical conformation (18.Matsuzaki T. Sasaki C. Okumura C. Umeyama H. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1989; 105: 949-952Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 19.Brandstetter H. Turk D. Hoeffken H.W. Grosse D. Sturzebecher J. Martin P.D. Edwards B.F.P. Bode W. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 226: 1085-1097Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar), we made the following docking study on the supposition that MNAPPA will bind the active sites of enzymes holding the same conformation as MQPA in1DWC. The crystallographic evidence has revealed that MQPA fits well into the active site of thrombin through its arginine side chain, quinolinesulfonyl group, and methylpiperidine group to the S1 specificity pocket, aryl binding pocket, and S2 cavity, respectively (10.Banner D.W. Hadvary P. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 20085-20093Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19.Brandstetter H. Turk D. Hoeffken H.W. Grosse D. Sturzebecher J. Martin P.D. Edwards B.F.P. Bode W. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 226: 1085-1097Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar). Our experimental results indicated that arginine derivatives lost their thrombin inhibitory activity but reserved trypsin inhibitory activity when a phenyl group was introduced into the 4-position of the piperidine ring (4, 7 and this report). To know the binding geometry of the 4-phenyl group, we visualized the C36 atom at thepara-position of 4-phenyl group attached to the piperidine ring of MQPA in 1DWC. As shown in Fig.3 A, C36 introduced into the MQPA molecule revealed severe steric clash against Tyr60Aof the “60-insertion loop” of thrombin. When MQPAC36 was superposed on other thrombin coordinates such as 1DWB, 1AHT, and 1FPC, every docking experiment resulted in similar steric collisions between C36 and Tyr60A. Fig. 3 A also shows trypsin superposed on MQPAC36-thrombin. In the case of trypsin, the 60-insertion loop is not present (Fig.4), and, therefore, there is no projecting obstacle but a sufficient space at the site. Consequently, C36 did not cause any clash against trypsin. Neither tetrahydro-8-quinolinesulfonyl group nor 7-oxy-2-naphthalenesulfonyl group collided with the enzyme. When we used other trypsin coordinates such as 2TBS, 1TPP, and 1PPC, similar results were obtainable showing no collision between ligand and enzyme. Fig. 3 B shows the MQPAC36-thrombin complex superposed on tryptase monomer A. Although tryptase has a 60-insertion loop, it does not protrude heavily as in thrombin, and, therefore, C36 did not collide with tryptase. However, the tetrahydro-8-quinolinesulfonyl group or 7-oxy-2-naphthalenesulfonyl group at the N terminus of the ligands collided with Gln98of tryptase. Similar results were obtained when the ligands were docked into the other monomers of tryptase (monomer B, C, and D). Our docking study suggests the following plausible explanation; the inhibitory effect of MNAPPA on thrombin is weak because the 4-phenyl group of MNAPPA collides with the 60- insertion loop of thrombin, and MNAPPA and MQPA do not inhibit tryptase because the 7-oxy-2-naphthalenesulfonyl and tetrahydro-8-quinolinesulfonyl group collide with tryptase. Consequently, MNAPPA has acquired the trypsin-selective inhibitory activity. In our previous reports, we described the strategies to obtain inhibitors selective to thrombin and those selective to trypsin respectively, among the derivatives of l-arginine (7.Hijikata-Okunomiya A. Okamoto S. Kikumoto R. Tamao Y. Ohkubo K. Tezuka T. Tonomura S. Matsumoto O. Thromb. Res. 1987; 45: 451-462Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 20.Hijikata-Okunomiya A. Okamoto S. Semin. Thromb. Hemostasis. 1992; 18: 135-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). The selective thrombin inhibitor MQPA is the representative of the former. In this report, we introduced MNAPPA as one of the representatives of the latter. The enzymes tested were trypsin, thrombin, plasmin, plasma kallikrein, urokinase, and tryptase, all of which are the key enzymes in the field of digestion, coagulation, fibrinolysis, kinin formation, and mast cell diseases. The enzyme inhibitory activities of MNAPPA as shown in Table I revealed that MNAPPA was a potent and selective trypsin inhibitor. Tryptase is a trypsin-like serine proteinase from mast cells. It hydrolyzes peptide bonds next to arginine and lysine residue (21.Tanaka T. McRae B.J. Cho K. Cook R. Fraki J.E. Johnson D.A. Powers J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 13552-13557Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, Pereira et al. (17.Pereira P.J Bergner A. Macedo-Ribeiro S. Huber R. Matschiner G. Fritz H. Sommerhoff C.P. Bode W. Nature. 1998; 392: 306-311Crossref PubMed Scopus (284) Google Scholar) revealed the x-ray crystallography of the complex of APA and tetrameric human tryptase; the specificity pocket of tryptase is virtually identical to that of trypsin to accommodate arginine and lysine side chain, the tryptase monomers are positioned at each corner of the tetramer, the active sites are directed to the center of the tetramer, and macromolecule substrates or inhibitors are restricted to access to the active site by the neighboring monomers. Therefore, the S1 site occupying compounds of small molecular weight such as benzamidine, APA, andN α-p-tosyl-l-lysine chloromethyl ketone inhibit tryptase and trypsin as well (22.Sturzebecher J. Prasa D. Sommerhoff C.P. Biol. Chem. Hoppe-Seyler. 1992; 373: 1025-1030Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 23.Smith T.J. Hougland D.A. Johnson D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 11046-11051Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Furthermore, studies on benzamidine and bis-benzamidine derivatives revealed that the affinities of these compounds to trypsin and tryptase are closely correlated (22.Sturzebecher J. Prasa D. Sommerhoff C.P. Biol. Chem. Hoppe-Seyler. 1992; 373: 1025-1030Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). None of the small molecular weight compounds had been reported to discriminate trypsin from tryptase precisely. Because the molecular weight of MNAPPA is small and comparable with those of antipain (M r = 605) and leupeptin (M r = 427), both of which inhibit trypsin and tryptase (Refs. 23.Smith T.J. Hougland D.A. Johnson D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 11046-11051Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar and 24.Aoyagi T. Umezawa H. Reich E. Rifkin D. Shaw E. Proteases and Biological Control. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1975: 429-454Google Scholar and this report), and because the arginine side chain of MNAPPA is assumed to be accommodated in the specificity pocket of tryptase, we expected that MNAPPA could access to the active site of tryptase to inhibit it. But it did not inhibit tryptase as shown in Table I. After we compared the enzyme inhibitory spectrum of MNAPPA with those of the established trypsin inhibitors such as leupeptin, antipain, and nafamostat mesilate as shown in Table II, we came to a conclusion that MNAPPA was the most selective trypsin inhibitor of small molecular weight ever reported. Rapidly advanced protein chemistry in recent years has provided much knowledge of three-dimensional structures of enzymes, allowing our understanding of enzyme functions at the molecular level. Selective proteinase inhibitors have been useful in the experimental procedures of crystallographic analysis of enzymes, and moreover, it is very helpful for visualizing the active sites of enzymes. Considering the steric hindrance between ligand and enzyme, we obtained visual models that agree with the experimental results of inhibition studies (Fig.3). The steric collision of 4-phenylpiperidine with 60-insertion loop especially seems to be a satisfactory explanation for the loss of thrombin inhibitory activity of MNAPPA, because the conformation of 60-insertion loop appeared rigid, and the same severe clash was also observed in other docking experiments using the coordinates of thrombin complexed with benzamidine, APA, and DAPA. Furthermore, steric hindrance between N terminus of the ligands and tryptase seemed probable, because the tilting of Gln98 might be restricted in tetrameric tryptase, because the active sites of monomer A and D (and those of B and C) are spacially close to each other, and Gln98 of monomer A and Tyr95 of monomer D are neighboring (17.Pereira P.J Bergner A. Macedo-Ribeiro S. Huber R. Matschiner G. Fritz H. Sommerhoff C.P. Bode W. Nature. 1998; 392: 306-311Crossref PubMed Scopus (284) Google Scholar). It has been reported that certain enzymes of trypsin families such as trypsin, thrombin, and tryptase cleave proteinase-activated receptors on the cell surface and trigger signals that regulate multiple cellular reactions (see review in Ref. 25.Dery O. Corvera C.U. Steinhoff M. Bunnett N.W. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: C1429-C1452Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Proteinase-activated receptor 2, the receptor for trypsin, is widely distributed in the body tissues such as the gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, kidney, liver, airway, and prostate and in endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, and certain tumor cell lines. In addition, endothelial cells and some cancer cells express trypsinogen, and gene expression of trypsinogen was increased in vascular endothelial cells around gastric tumors and in patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation (26.Koshikawa N. Nagashima Y. Miyagi Y. Mizushima H. Yanoma S. Yasumitsu H. Miyazaki K. FEBS Lett. 1997; 409: 442-448Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). Furthermore, trypsin may escape into the circulation during pancreatitis. The selective trypsin inhibitor MNAPPA may be a useful tool to elucidate the roles of trypsin in the pathogenesis of various diseases.
